abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, project outcome is rated
            satisfactory; project objectives were fully achieved. The
            project showed that an autonomous, privately managed, local
            agency is capable of executing works efficiently and
            effectively on behalf of public institutions, without the
            help of external technical assistance. Some key lessons
            learned are the following: 1) Quality of construction needs
            to be a priority: the Public Works Executing Agency needs to
            be more careful in its selection process, give more
            attention to sub-project supervision, hold
            design/engineering firms accountable for quality, and
            emphasize training 2) The project was able to break the
            oligopoly in the construction industry by opening up
            opportunities for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). By
            anticipating the strengthening and development of SMEs,
            future projects might be able to address both the
            sustainability concern and quality concerns, and produce
            larger efficiency gains. 3) Any future project should
            consider the need to strengthen municipal capacity,
            especially for operations and maintenance. This includes
            both technical and managerial capacity, as well as improving
            revenue generation and tax collection. 4) The Agency needs
            to visualize its future as an independent entity performing
            a service for a fee. 5) Once the concept of delegated
            contract management municipalities is accepted and supported
            in a country, municipalities should have a choice in which
            agency they employ for the delegation of contract management.
